sen.j: イワツツノオ（イハツツノヲ）は、日本神話に登場する神 (神道)である。
sen.e: Iwatsutsunoo (Ihatsutsunowo) is a god (god of Shinto) featured in Japanese Mythology.
Iwatsutsunoo (Ihatsutsunowo) is a god (god of Shinto) featured in Japanese Mythology.
Iwatsutsunoo (Ihatsutsunowo) is a god (god of Shinto) featured in Japanese Mythology.

sen.j: 古事記では石筒之男神、日本書紀では磐筒男神と表記される。
sen.e: He is referred to as Iwatsutsu-no-onokami in Kojiki (The Records of Ancient Matters), and Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan).
He is referred to as Iwatsutsu-no-onokami in Kojiki (The Records of Ancient Matters), and Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan).
Iwatsutsunoo is described as 石筒之男神 in Kojiki (Records of Ancient Matters), and as 磐筒男神 in Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan).

sen.j: 古事記の神産みの段でイザナギが十束剣で、妻のイザナミの死因となった火神カグツチの首を斬ったとき、その剣の先についた血が岩について化生した神である。
sen.e: In the Kamiumi-no-dan (the Chapter of Bearing Gods) of Kojiki, when Izanagi cut the god of fire Kagutsuchi, which had caused death to his wife Izanami, on the neck with his sword Totsuka no tsurugi, Iwatsutsunoo was born from the blood on the sword.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In the Kamiumi-no-dan (the Chapter of Bearing Gods) of Kojiki, when Izanagi cut the god of fire Kagutsuchi, which had caused death to his wife Izanami, on the neck with his sword Totsuka no tsurugi, Iwatsutsunoo was born from the blood on the sword.

In the Kamiumi-no-dan (the Chapter of Bearing Gods) of Kojiki, when Izanagi cut the god of fire Kagutsuchi, which had caused death to his wife Izanami, on the neck with his sword Totsuka no tsurugi, Iwatsutsunoo was born from the blood on the sword which dropped on the rock.

sen.j: その前にイワサク・ネサク（磐裂神・根裂神）が化生している。
sen.e: Before him, Iwasaku (a god who splits a rock) and Nesaku (a god who splits a root) were also born from the same blood.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Before him, Iwasaku (a god who splits a rock) and Nesaku (a god who splits a root) were also born from the same blood.
Before him, Iwasaku (a god who splits a rock) and Nesaku (a god who splits a root) were also born from the same blood.

sen.j: 日本書紀同段の第六の一書も同様で、ここでは磐筒男神は経津主神の祖であると記されている。
sen.e: There is a similar explanation about his birth in the sixth "alternate writing" of the Kamiumi-no-dan, Nihonshoki, and Iwatsutsu-no-onokami was alleged to be an ancestor of Futsunushi no kami.
There is a similar explanation about his birth in the sixth "alternate writing" of the Kamiumi-no-dan, Nihonshoki, and Iwatsutsu-no-onokami was alleged to be an ancestor of Futsunushi no kami.
There is a similar explanation about his birth in the sixth "alternate writing" of the Kamiumi no dan, Nihonshoki, and Iwatsutsu no onokami was alleged to be an ancestor of Futsunushi no kami.

sen.j: 日本書紀同段の第七の一書では、磐裂神・根裂神の子として磐筒男神・磐筒女神が生まれたとし、この両神の子が経津主神であるとしている。
sen.e: According to the seventh "alternative writing" of the same Chapter, Iwasaku and Nesaku gave birth to Iwatsutsu-no-onokami and Iwatsutsu-no-menokami, who in turn gave birth to Futsunushi no kami.
According to the seventh "alternative writing" of the same Chapter, Iwasaku and Nesaku gave birth to Iwatsutsu-no-onokami and Iwatsutsu-no-menokami, who in turn gave birth to Futsunushi no kami.
According to the seventh "alternative writing" of the same Chapter, Iwasaku and Nesaku gave birth to Iwatsutsu no onokami and Iwatsutsu no menokami, who in turn gave birth to Futsunushi no kami.

sen.j: 神名の「ツツ」は「カグツチ」「ノヅチ」などの「ツチ」と同じ「～の神霊」の意で、「イワツツノオ」は「岩の男神」の意となる。
sen.e: "Tsutsu" in his name means "the divine sprit of …"like "tsuchi" in "Kagutsuchi" and "Nozuchi," and so "Iwatsutsunoo" means "a male god of rock."
"Tsutsu" in his name means "the divine sprit of …"like "tsuchi" in "Kagutsuchi" and "Nozuchi," and so "Iwatsutsunoo" means "a male god of rock."
Tsutsu' in his name means 'the divine sprit of …'like 'tsuchi' in 'Kagutsuchi' and 'Nozuchi,' and so 'Iwatsutsunoo' means 'a male god of rock.'

sen.j: ただし、橘守部は、イワサク・ネサクを「岩根さえも裂く剣の威力」を表すと解したのに対応して、「イワツツ」は「石槌」で、剣を鍛える槌のことであるとしている。
sen.e: However, TACHIBANA no Moribe interpreted "Iwatsutsu" as "a stone hammer," a hammer used to beetle a sword, in accordance with his interpretation of Iwasaku and Nesaku as "the power of a sword that splits even rock-roots."

However, TACHIBANA no Moribe interpreted "Iwatsutsu" as "a stone hammer," a hammer used to beetle a sword, in accordance with his interpretation of Iwasaku and Nesaku as "the power of a sword that splits even rock-roots."
